content:
Executive Summary 14 DEC 25 at approx 1845 local time two confirmed gunmen armed with 1x shotgun and possibly 2x long rifles fired fired on civilian at Archer park at Bondi Beach, Sydney. Reporting indicates at least 10 dead including one of the shooters. Over 15 injured including two police. Has been declared a terrorist attack targeting the Sydney Jewish community. Context At around 1845 local time (0845 Zulu time) at Bondi Beach, Sydney, Australia. Two gunmen were recorded shooting from a pedestrian bridge to the north of the Bondi Beach Pavilion. The men were armed with a confirmed shotgun, and PROBABLY two rifles, caliber unknown.
Both gunmen were neutralized by police, with video showing one gunmen PROBABLY deceased and the other gunmen LIKELY alive though in a serious condition.
Reporting indicates that at least nine civilians are deceased with 11 reported injured, alongside 2 injured police officers.
Speculation online has indicated that the shooting is religiously motivated. This is unconfirmed. Chabad of Bondi did advertise an event at the same time and place as the shooting which is a strong indicator. The gunmen’s location was less than 100m from the event location and less than 50 meters from a filmed location showing mass casualty treatment. Further reporting is required to confirm the motive of the attack.
It is ALMOST CERTAIN that Australian police services will conduct an in depth investigation to determine the motive of the attacks. If it is determined to be a religiously motivated attack, there will LIKELY be links between the gunmen and groups backed by Iran or it’s proxies. This would be a strong indicator that Iranian backed groups hold influence within Australia and could LIKELY organize additional attacks against Jewish groups in Australia. Domestic security posture will ALMOST CERTAINLY increase over the Australian holiday season.
Analysis was conducted via geolocation of social media videos, online research of local events and interviews/reports by local media outlets. All information is independently gathered, aggregated and assessed.
Probability Indicators Probability < 10% < 25% > 25% > 50% > 75% > 90% Wording DOUBTFUL UNLIKELY POSSIBLE LIKELY PROBABLE ALMOST CERTAIN
summary: 14 DEC 25 at approx 1845 local time two confirmed gunmen opened fire at Bondi Beach, Sydney.
title: SITREP - 14 DEC 25 - Bondi Shooting

content:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY Father Sajid Akram and son Naveed Akram were ALMOST CERTAINLY acting on behalf of Islamic State (IS) ideologies. Naveed was LIKELY originally exposed to radicalization by Isaak El Matari back in 2019. At that time, during ASIO’s investigation of Naveed, he LIKELY didn’t show any signs of radicalization and its POSSIBLE these beliefs faded. Increased Israel/Gaza tensions PROBABLY reigniting Naveed’s radicalization, which was then shared and developed in his father Sajid. It is UNLIKELY that other individuals linked to Isaak El Matari were involved, however this will ALMOST CERTAINLY be a line of investigation for police.
Father Sajid Akram (50 years) and son Naveed Akram (24 years) have been positively identified as the two shooters involved in the Bondi Beach attack. Reports have indicated that an IS flag was recovered from the shooters vehicle. They both lived in the same residence in Bonnyrigg, and both stayed at an AirBnb in Campsie prior to the attack.
https://external-content.duckduckgo.com/iu/?u=https%3A%2F%2Fe3.365dm.com%2F25%2F12%2F1600x900%2Fskynews-bondi-beach-sydney_7109804.jpg%3F20251214161242&f=1&nofb=1&ipt=cda2a8f90d7d31d5bb9b4080cfbd48643a6cc1e1332ea98aaf839162311a4341
Fig 1: Naveed Aktram (left) and Sajid Akram (right) during the shooting.
Sajid Akram emigrated to Australia on a student visa in 1998 where his son Naveed was born in 2001. Both father and son lived under the same roof in Bonnyrig which was investigated by police following the Bondi Shooting. Sajid Akram was the licensed gun holder, and has legally held firearms for 10 years without concern.
Officials stated that Naveed Akram had been under assessment for 6 months back in 2019 following Naveed’s connection to Isaak El Matari. It was reported that they were acquaintances though the strength of their connection is unknown at this time. Following this assessment period (2019/2020) it was determined that Naveed was not a threat to safety
COMMENT. Isaak El Matari, from Greenacres, Sydney, was arrested in 2019 following an investigation that revealed he had become radicalized by IS, and had planned to travel to Afghanistan to support IS fighters in the area. He was self proclaimed to be the commander of IS in Australia but during his trial the judge declared that Matari didn’t have “the slighted idea” how to conduct the plans he had discussed with others. It was reported that he was without weapons or followers. He was sentenced in 2021 and is still in prison. END COMMENT.
ASSESSMENT. It is PROBABLE that the son, Naveed, radicalized his father. These radical beliefs LIKELY began from contact with Isaak El Matari back in 2019, though they PROBABLY remained latent until recent international conflict reignited radical ideologies. It is ALMOST CERTAIN that Sajid and Naveed planned the attack in their Bonnyrigg residence, LIKELY no planning communications took place over phone/email/etc, drastically reducing national intelligence agencies ability to investigate further. It is UNLIKELY that other individuals connected to Isaak El Matari were involved in the planning of the attack, however this will ALMOST CERTAINLY be a line of investigation for police.
Sources Sydney Morning Herald
ABC
SBS-1
SBS-2
News.com
Probability Indicators Probability < 10% < 25% > 25% > 50% > 75% > 90% Wording DOUBTFUL UNLIKELY POSSIBLE LIKELY PROBABLE ALMOST CERTAIN
summary: OSINT analysis of Bondi Shooters IS links, reporting current at time of creation.
title: SITREP - 15 DEC 25 - Analyzing the Bondi Shooter's Islamic State Links

content:
Weekly Intelligence Digest - 20251212 A concise, structured summary of the week’s most relevant developments across security, cyber, geopolitics, organised crime and national resilience in the Pacific.
1. (Japan/Philippines) Informal talks over Type 03 SAM sales Reporting indicates that Japan and the Philippines have held informal talks regarding the sale of Type 03 Medium Range Surface to Air missiles (Chu-SAM). Designed to engage all air platforms, the Japanese Type 03 is capable of neutralizing low flying ballistic and cruise missiles.
COMMENT: The addition of the Type 03 to the Filipino integrated air defense system would provide improved native defensive capabilities against Chinese rocket forces.
ANALYSIS: It is PROBABLE that Japan is interested in enhancing other South East Asian nation capabilities to deter Chinese military operations in the South China Sea. These early discussions LIKELY developed as a result of recent disputes between Japan and China and China will PROBABLY retaliate in the coming weeks. Japan developing military trade relationships with other South East Asian nations would be a strong indicator of strategic retaliation against China.
Asia Times Missilery
2. (Japan/China) PLA-N use active radar as China/Japan dispute continues Japan reported that PLA-N directed active radar at Japanese F-15 jets operating in the vicinity of disputed islands near Okinawa. China claims that Japan was made aware of the"Standard maritime activity in the area" and that Japan is merely fanning flames.
ANALYSIS: Military interactions will PROBABLY continue, with POSSIBLE maritime disputes resulting in coast guard/fishing boat clashes. It is LIKELY that these military run ins will continue and POSSIBLY escalate over the next 30 days. Continued military cooperation between Japan and other South East Asian Nation’s will LIKELY continue as a strategic response to China’s aggression. China will PROBABLY respond with increase maritime incursions and military signalling.
NY Times
3. (Papua New Guinea/Bougainville) Bougainville independence in ‘final leg’ of planning by PNG Representatives from PNG and Bougainville held talks this week at Port Moresby over the future of the autonomous region of Bougainville. Following the non-binding Bougainville independence referendum in 2019, PNG declared that it would ratify the result. The process by which this would be conducted has been unclear and Bougainville locals have concerns that PNG leaders were dragging the chain full ratification. PNG however has stated that they are in the final leg in which the referendum results will go to parliament. This is anticipated for the first half of 2026. Reports indicate that PNG leaders are sensitive to setting a precedent for other parts of the country wishing to break away.
COMMENT: Bougainville has long sought independence from PNG dating back to the Bougainville Conflict, spanning from 1988-1998. This saw extensive fighting between PNG, Australian and Indonesia against Bougainville, Solomon islands and allegedly Fiji. This conflict was finalized by the establishment of the Autonomous Bougainville Government which since then has wanted to become fully independent.
ANALYSIS: The ratification of Bougainville’s independence would ALMOST CERTAINLY require extensive support from PNG and other Pacific powers to ensure ongoing government stability. China would PROBABLY leverage their positive relationship with the Solomon Islands to position themselves to engage Bougainville economically. As a newly independent nation they will ALMOST CERTAINLY be susceptible to coercion, making Bougainville a strategically valuable, and vulnerable, Pacific Island Nation.
RNZ Bougainville Conflict
Watch List - Next 7 Days Japanese arms agreements with other Pacific nations. Escalating military tensions between Japan/China Probability Indicators Probability < 10% < 25% > 25% > 50% > 75% > 90% Wording DOUBTFUL UNLIKELY POSSIBLE LIKELY PROBABLE ALMOST CERTAIN
summary: China/Japanese tensions and Papua New Guinea/Bougainville developments.
title: Weekly Digest 13 DEC 2025

content:
Weekly Intelligence Digest - 20251128 A concise, structured summary of the week’s most relevant developments across security, cyber, geopolitics, organised crime and national resilience.
1. (US/JAPAN/CHINA) Military Development at Yonaguni Island Reporting indicates that since September 2025, US marines have conducted multiple logistics missions supplying the Japanese island of Yonaguni with medical supplies and disaster response equipment, including refrigeration units. This was done as part of exercise Resolute Dragon 2025. Reporting shows that Japan has announced it will be deploying the Type 03 medium-range surface to air missile launchers (Chū-SAM Kai) on Yonaguni. China has responded with firm verbal threats if Japan was to become involved in a Taiwan conflict.
COMMENT. The island of Yonaguni is positioned 110km to the east of Taiwan, within China’s “First Island Defense Line”. It acts as a key surveillance and anti-access hub in the East China Sea. END COMMENT
ASSESSMENT. Japan and America are ALMOST CERTAINLY positioning supplies at Yonaguni with the intention of it acting as a forward base of operations in the event of a Taiwan conflict. The presence of refrigerant indicates LIKELY blood storage, as such it will be a key medical hub/casualty evacuation center. The positioning of Japanese surface to air missiles is PROBABLY to enhance anti-access and area denial of eastern approaches to Taiwan. Chinese missile capabilities would PROBABLY overwhelm the Type 03 (Chū-SAM Kai) if Yonaguni was targeted. China will PROBABLY take retaliatory economic actions to cohere Japan and POSSIBLY conduct military drills/exercises as a show of force. It is UNLIKELY that this will result in a flash point for conflict in the Pacific.
Asia Times
TheJapanTimes
2. (Pacific Nations) The Lowy Institute has released the Pacific Power Ratings for 2025 The Lowy Institute is a strategic think tank that has released the 2025 Pacific Power Ratings. The ratings are generated from detailed analysis outlining power and influence in the Pacific. Notable results from the 2025 study show that the US has marginally fallen in power, though still remaining in the top position. China has shown a noticeable increase and Russia has retaking the 5th position moving Australia to 6th. India has also positioned itself as a “Major Power” in the region.
Lowy Institute Pacific Power Ratings 2025
3. (Tonga/China) Tonga and China confirm 9 Memorandums of Understanding Tongan King Tupou VI and President Xi Junping have wrapped up their meetings in Beijing with the reported signing of 9 memorandums of understanding. These are said to develop closer bilateral ties in terms of medical assistance, education, trade, economic development, people to people relations and green power. Reports from Reuters shows that Tonga is heavily indebted to China’s EXIm Bank, with World Bank data showing it owes Beijing $112 million, accounting for 48% of Tongas external debt. This is largly construction loans through the Belt and Road Initiative.
Australia has allocated $17.49 million to help boost climate change and rising sea levels, while the US committed $4.1 million in 2024.
COMMENT. Tonga is a small pacific island of approx. 108,000 people. Much of the Belt and Road Initiative construction work is done in part by Chinese nationals and State Owned Enterprises. END COMMENT
ASSESSMENT. China ALMOST CERTAINLY sees Tonga as a valuable ally to allow freedom of movement throughout the Pacific. The promotion of the Belt and Road Initiative in Tonga ALMOST CERTAINLY allows Chinese state owned enterprises to develop and maintain port and road infrastructure as well as conduct surveillance of the nation. It is PROBABLE that China will seek to enhance security and defense cooperation with Tonga in the coming years. This will LIKELY cause increased friction between China and Western powers.
Reuters
Matangi Tonga
4. (Australia/Tonga/China) Australia and Solomon Islands $190 mil policing deal delayed Reporting indicates that Australia and the Solomon islands have made little progress in the $190 million deal to grow the size and capability of the Royal Solomon Islands Police Force (RSIFP) as well as build an enduring sovereign security capability. The deal was set to take place over four years however the agreement hasn’t yet been confirmed. There are reports that there are “One or two differences” preventing the memorandum of understanding from being signed.
COMMENT. China has established a Solomon Islands Police Training Force that has provided hands on training to RSIFP members both within the Solomon Islands and Fujian Police Collage in China. END COMMENT
ASSESSMENT. It is LIKELY that the Solomon Islands Government is hesitant to sign an agreement that would strain continued cooperation with China, particularly on matters of police training and infrastructure projects. China would PROBABLY coerce the Solomon Islands into maintaining their close security ties by using financial motivators. Solomon Islands LIKELY wants to adjust the proposed Australian policing deal to be less committal and allow continued support from both countries.
ABC News
Watch List - Next 7 Days Yonaguni Island developments, particularly around Chinese Economic responses to Japan. Probability Indicators Probability < 10% < 25% > 25% > 50% > 75% > 90% Wording DOUBTFUL UNLIKELY POSSIBLE LIKELY PROBABLE ALMOST CERTAIN
summary: China/Japanese tensions, UK naval weaponary developments and increased domestic tensions in the Philippines.

title: Weekly Digest 28 NOV 2025

content:
Executive Summary 1-3 bullets summarising the main answer to the key question. Written for a busy reader who may only read this section. Clearly state scope, time frame and focuse. Key Judgements KJ1 First key judgement in one sentence, with scome and time frame plus probability indicator.
KJ2
KJ3
Context Briefly describe:
Who is involved What the issue is Why it matters The time frame Definitions or assumptions. Evidence and Open Sources Summarise the main sources used, by type:
Official public documents Media reporting (described by theme, not outlet if preferred) Public datasets Academic / NGO / Think tank analysis Other OSINT (imagery, social media etc.) Analysis Explain how the evidence leads to the key judgements.
Describe mechanisms, drivers and constraints Discuss alternative explainations where relevant Highlight areas of uncertainty and gaps in reporting Be explicit: what is inference, what is directly observed Implications Describe why this matters, for whom and in what time frame.
Implications for Australia and the Indo-Pacific etc. Policy, economic or security implications Possible second and third order effects Outlook Provided a bounded outlook in time:
Assessed developments Key uncertainties Indicators that would strengthen or weaken assessment Method Notes Briefly note:
Any structured analytical techniquest used (trend analysis, competing hypothesis etc.) Key limitations in data Any important caveats for interpretation.
summary: One or two sentences summarising the core question and the score of the report.
title: REPORT TITLE - SHORT, DESCRIPTIVE
